migration tool for Postgres. In true Graphile style, it is simple, familiar,

frontmatter.title: Graphile Migrate Reaches 1.0
frontmatter.thumbnailAlt: Cartoon people release red arrows up into the sky
frontmatter.summary: Graphile Migrate 1.0  has been released; after many months of use and testing, Migrate is ready to move from 'experimental' into stable v1.0.0. There are no breaking changes in this release, there is now support for a gmrc file and a few minor fixes.

post.excerpt:
Announced 2020-11-27 by Team Graphile Improved Framework Support The major feature in this release is vastly improved support for various Node.js
webserver frameworks, including: Node itself, Connect, Express, Koa, Fastify (v2
and v3), and Restify…

frontmatter.title: PostGraphile Releases Version 4.10 - Framework Friends
frontmatter.thumbnailAlt: A gallery wall of frames containing blank blue images
frontmatter.summary: Graphile is pleased to announce the release of PostGraphile version 4.10, an upgrade introducing better support for various Node.js webserver frameworks, an upgraded GraphiQL and GraphiQL Explorer, and improvements added by our community members.

frontmatter.title: Benjie's story at the GitHub ReadME project
frontmatter.summary: This week, Benjie was profiled by the GitHub ReadME project, a new endeavour to collect stories from open source maintainers and amplify their voices to the wider developer community.

post.excerpt:
Announced 2020-08-05 by the Graphile Team Enum Tables PostGraphile now supports "enum tables"; we have previously recommended against
using PostgreSQL enums if the enums are ever likely to change after creation.
This is because PostgreSQL enums…

frontmatter.title: PostGraphile Releases Version 4.8 - Excellent Enums
frontmatter.thumbnailAlt: A developer sat at a desk with a computer monitor and laptop
frontmatter.summary: Graphile is pleased to announce the release of PostGraphile version 4.8.0, an upgrade recommended for all PostGraphile users, which introduces support for enum tables and geometric types.

post.excerpt:
Announced 2020-07-21 by Team Graphile We've built a service (using Graphile Starter) that will analyze your database
design against a list of rules we've compiled over the last few years of
consultancy and support, explains any detected issues, and…

frontmatter.title: Graphile Team Releases pgRITA - a Tool for Postgres
frontmatter.summary: pgRITA analyzes your database schema against our rules, compiling an interactive report that helps your engineers to build secure, robust and performant databases.

post.excerpt:

organization is a group of users (such as a charity, workspace or team) where
one user is "in charge" and one person is a…

frontmatter.title: Graphile Starter 3.0 - Organize your Organizations!
frontmatter.thumbnailAlt: Woman holding a lightbulb which contains the number 3.0
frontmatter.summary: Graphile Starter 3.0 brings with it support for organizations - including all of the behaviour you would expect such as creating and managing users, sending and accepting invites and other management controls.

frontmatter.title: Graphile Migrate 0.1 Released
frontmatter.thumbnailAlt: Cartoon people release red arrows up into the sky
frontmatter.summary: Graphile Migrate 0.1 is a big milestone for the project, with it finally leaving 0.0.x territory - That's right, it's no longer 'Highly' experimental! This release is a significant jump from the previous versions and includes many new commands, more configuration options, and a suite of new features.

post.excerpt:
Announced 2020-02-05 by Team Graphile Graphile Worker is a job queue for PostgreSQL running on Node.js. It allows you
to run jobs (e.g. sending emails, performing calculations, generating PDFs, etc)
"in the background" so that your HTTP response…

frontmatter.title: Graphile Worker 0.4 released
frontmatter.thumbnailAlt: A cartoon man runs towards the red Graphile heart logo
frontmatter.summary: Today, Graphile Worker 0.4 has been released. This version includes significantly enhanced performance gains, a dedicated API for queuing jobs from TypeScript, and the ability to run jobs in parallel.
